journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: On the stabilising effect of gyroscopic moments in an automotive turbocharger

article-meta.aff: 1Institute of Sound and Vibration Research, University of Southampton, UK
2Departamento do Engenharia Mecânica, UNESP, Ilha Solteira, Brazil
3School of Engineering Sciences, University of Southampton, UK

author-notes.corresp: Punithavathy Kamesh, Institute of Sound and Vibration Research, University of Southampton, Southampton S017 1BJ, UK. Email: punitha.kamesh777@gmail.com

abstract.p: Automotive turbochargers, which operate at very high speeds, exceeding 180,000 r/min, exhibit two strong sub-harmonic modes of vibrations due to oil-whirl instability. These are a conical mode and an in-phase whirl mode. The gyroscopic effects can be very important in such a rotor system. This article presents a theoretical investigation into these effects on the conical whirl instability of a turbocharger induced by the angular (tilting) motion of a rigid rotor. A simplified linear model is used to analyse the rotor-bearing system by investigating the effects of the gyroscopic moment on the internal moments. A gyroscopic coefficient, defined by the geometry of the rotor, is shown to govern the stability of the conical whirl motion. A threshold value of ½ is determined for this coefficient to suppress the conical whirl. This value remains unaffected if the rotor is asymmetric and is supported by floating ring bearings, which is the case in a practical turbocharger.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Turbochargers are a special class of turbo-machinery used to improve diesel engine efficiency by utilising the energy in the exhaust gases. Automotive turbochargers are characterised by their high speed of operation and light-weight rotors. Two sub-synchronous modes, corresponding to in-phase and conical whirl motions of the rotor, typically occur during operation.1 Waterfall diagrams of turbocharger vibrations reveal strong sub-harmonic vibrations corresponding to these modes, regardless of the bearing designs.2 They exist over most of the speed range, typically from 30,000 to 180,000 r/min. These whirl modes can produce large-amplitude alternating stresses in the rotor, creating fatigue that can result in shaft failure.3 They also cause a low frequency rumble, and can be of large amplitude at high speeds leading to rotor–stator rub. Most commercial automotive turbochargers use floating ring bearings due to their low cost.4

Several analytical and experimental investigations have been conducted to investigate the dynamic performance of the floating ring bearings. To cite a few, Alsaeed,5 using the computer program DyRoBeS,6 showed that the external damping due to the outer-film can re-stabilise the whirling modes. Gunter and Chen7 analytically showed the existence of limit cycles at speeds of 100,000 r/min and higher due to the non-linear behaviour of the fluid-film floating ring bearings. San Andres and Kerth8 also analysed the non-linear response of a turbocharger with these bearings considering the thermal effects on the bearing performance. Holt et al.4 experimentally showed the absence of sub-synchronous whirling above 90,000 r/min in a turbocharger with floating ring bearings. Predictions of the limit cycle response of these turbochargers require non-linear analysis.4 However, the frequencies of the two sub-synchronous modes can be predicted using a linear model of the system.4 Alsaeed5 investigated several hydrodynamic journal bearings, demonstrating the benefit of linear analysis for design evaluation and maintenance purposes.

Holmes2 proposed a simple linear model of a turbocharger with floating ring (outer-film modelled as an external damper) and press-fit bearings. Using a rigid symmetric rotor, and assuming an oil-film of 360° extent, he predicted the behaviour of the in-phase whirl frequency, which qualitatively agreed with waterfall plots from typical commercial turbochargers. Holmes et al.9 extended the investigation using an asymmetric model to determine the frequencies of the two whirl modes, again showing qualitative agreement with a typical turbocharger.

One feature of the dynamic behaviour of a turbocharger experimentally observed is that the two whirl frequencies sometimes co-exist for all speeds, sometimes for only some speeds and sometimes there is only one whirl frequency for all speeds. For example, Figure 1(a) shows a waterfall plot of a turbocharger where both the modes are seen in the given speed range. In Figure 1(b), the waterfall plot shows only the second mode for the same speed range. Tondl10 suggested that gyroscopic action could reduce the amplitude of self-excited vibration and for a fairly large gyroscopic moment, it may even suppress it completely. Figure 1.
(a) Typical waterfall plot showing the two sub-synchronous modes seen in a turbocharger and (b) waterfall plot showing only one of the sub-synchronous modes (Provided by Cummins turbo-technologies Ltd).

The aim of this article, therefore, is to investigate the effect of the gyroscopic moment on the conical whirl mode instability in a turbocharger by developing the simple model described by Holmes, et al.9

sec.title: Gyroscopic effect in a symmetric rotor-bearing system
sec.p:
Figure 2 shows a typical automotive turbocharger assembly. Since the steel turbine disc is much heavier than the aluminium compressor disc of a turbocharger, the centre of gravity of the turbocharger is near to the turbine bearing centre. Hence the turbocharger is modelled as an asymmetric rotor. In a floating ring bearing such as that shown in Figure 2, a ring separates the oil-film of the bearing into an inner-film and an outer-film. The ring usually rotates but in some configurations, the ring is pinned to the bearing and not allowed to rotate. In such cases, the ring experiences a precession. This is the case considered in this article. The inner-film of the floating ring bearing can be modelled as a hydrodynamic bearing and the outer-film can be modelled as an external damper in series with the bearing.2,9 The stiffness of the outer-film is assumed to be negligible compared to the damping in the squeezing action of the ring on the outer-film. For the sake of simplicity, the outer-film is thus assumed to act as a linear viscous damper. This assumption was used in the model developed by Holmes,2 in which qualitative agreement was shown between the predicted and the experimental waterfall plots. Although it is a gross simplicity, it avoids complicated mathematical modelling which enables better physical insight. Before conducting a numerical analysis of this system, a study is first conducted into a simple system containing a symmetric rotor mounted in rigidly-supported bearings rather than floating ring bearings. This allows analytical expressions to be derived which give physical insight into the interplay of the internal moments. The influence of the gyroscopic moment on the rest of the moments is revealed and the stability of the system is studied. Figure 2.
(a) A typical turbocharger––assembly of compressor disc, turbine disc and two identical floating ring bearings. Note that the distances la and lb are not shown to scale for clarity. Since the turbine is much heavier than the compressor, the centre of gravity is close to the turbine bearing centre. (b) A typical floating ring bearing with oil holes which supply oil from the outer-film to the inner-film. The outer-film is between the bearing and the ring, and the inner-film is between the ring and the rotor (Cummins turbo-technologies Ltd).

Figure 3 shows schematic diagrams of a symmetric model of a turbocharger with two identical journal bearings supported in rigid housings, which is representative of the simple system described above. Figure 3(a) shows a cross-section through each bearing with the oil-film greatly exaggerated. Figure 3(b) shows the schematic of the rotor-bearing system with two identical bearings with rigid backing. Figure 3(c) shows the co-ordinate system (for clarity, the discs representing the turbine and the compressor at each end of the shaft are not shown). Only tilting motion and the moments due to the oil-film forces and the moments from the gyroscopic action are of interest here. The rigid rotor has a mass 2m and transverse moment of inertia I. It is mounted in two identical bearings of 360° oil-film (i.e. no cavitation or oil-film rupture11). The angular co-ordinates about the s and r axes are θ and ϕ, respectively, and I is the distance between the bearing centres. Since the rotor is light-weight, the static displacement due to the self-weight of the rotor in the clearance is assumed to be negligible compared to the dynamic displacement. Given the assumptions mentioned above, and for a balanced rotor, the equation of angular motion of the rotor is given by (1)Iθ··+JωΓθ·+υ=0 where θ={θφ}T in which T denotes the transpose, J is the polar moment of inertia of the rotor assembly and Γ= [01-10 ] couples the two equations giving Γθ·={φ·,-θ·}T; υ={MsMr}T; Mr=-Fsl and Ms=-Frl are the moments about r and s axes, respectively, due to the oil-film forces Fr, Fs in the bearings; JωΓθ· is the gyroscopic moment due to the angular momentum Jω about the spin axis z shown in Figure 3(c). When the spinning rotor tilts about the s axis by angle θ, it experiences a moment about r axis as shown in Figure 3(c). A similar moment causes angular acceleration of the system about the s axis due to a tilt ϕ about r. The gyroscopic effect cross-couples the angular motion about the axes s and r. The linearised oil-film forces are used here. These are determined by integrating the pressure profile given by the Reynolds equation based on the short-bearing approximation, and using the full-film condition.11 The forces for each bearing are given by (2)f=2Ar·1+AωΓr1 where r1={r1,s1}T,f={Fr,Fs}T; A=πηL2R/(2C3) in which η is the viscosity of the oil; L and R are the length and radius of the bearing, respectively, and C is the bearing clearance. For small displacements, the angular co-ordinates θ, ϕ can be written in terms of the linear co-ordinates r1,s1 as (3)θ=2l{r1-s1}T Figure 3.
Schematic diagrams of a symmetric model of a turbocharger with two identical journal bearings supported in rigid housings. (a) Cross-section through each bearing; CB is the bearing centre; CJS is the static journal centre; CJD is the dynamic journal centre; O is the centre of the stationary casing and ω is the speed of rotation of the rotor. (b) Schematic of the rotor-bearing system. (c) Co-ordinate system: θ and ϕ are the angular co-ordinates about s and r, respectively; Jω is the angular momentum of the rotor with polar moment of inertia J about its spin axis z and I is the distance between the bearings.
Substituting for Fr and Fs from equation (2) and using the transformation in equation (3) and the corresponding derivative, equation (1) becomes (4)Iθ··+Al2θ·+JωΓθ·+Al2ω2Γθ=0

Dividing by Iωk 2, where ωk=Al2/I and assuming that θ=Θeλt and φ=Φeλt, equation (4) can be written as (5)[s¯2+s¯Ω(1/2+βs¯)-Ω(1/2+βs¯)s¯2+s¯]{ΘΦ}=0 where s¯=λ/ωk,Ω=ω/ωk and β=J/I is the gyroscopic coefficient, which is the ratio of the polar moment of inertia to the transverse moment of inertia of the rotor assembly. Equation (5) can be further simplified by noting that the matrix equations can be summed as Θ+jΦ, because of the 90° phase difference between Θ and Φ, and the model is symmetric. Thus, equation (5) becomes (6)s¯2+(1-jβΩ)s¯-jΩ/2=0

Equation (6) describes the dynamic behaviour of the symmetric rotor system in its simplified form, which can now be analysed to determine the stability of the conical whirl motion. The behaviour of the system without the gyroscopic effects is first considered by setting β = 0 to give (7)s¯2+s¯-j(Ω/2)=0 which is a quadratic equation representing the sum of three non-dimensional moments: s¯2, the inertial moment, s¯ the damping moment and -j(Ω/2), the cross-coupled stiffness moment. Solving equation (7) for s¯ gives (8)s¯1,2=(-1±1+j2Ω) /2 where s¯1 is an unstable root with a positive real part and s¯2 a stable root with a negative real part. The real parts of these roots are plotted in Figure 4 to illustrate their behaviour as the speed changes. Figure 4.
Graph showing the relationship between non-dimensional speed and the real part of the roots of the characteristic equation of angular motion of a simplified model of a turbocharger.

The way in which the internal moments change as a function of speed can be determined by substituting the unstable and stable roots from equations (8) into (7). The real and imaginary parts of the moments corresponding to the unstable and stable roots are plotted in Figure 5(a) and (b), respectively. For the phase reference considered, it can be seen that for the unstable root, the damping and the inertial moments have real and imaginary parts, while the cross-coupled stiffness moment is purely imaginary and negative. The imaginary parts of the inertia and the damping moments combine to balance the cross-coupled stiffness moment, and the real parts of the damping and inertia moments are equal and opposite to each other. However, the real part of the damping moment is positive and it is this that makes the system unstable. Figure 5.
Argand diagram of the moments from: (a) the unstable root and (b) the stable root of the characteristic equation of angular motion of a turbocharger with journal bearings in rigid housings without gyroscopic effects (0≤Ω≤10).

Conversely, moments from the stable root give damping with a negative real part and inertia with a positive real part as shown in Figure 5(b). The cross-coupled stiffness moment is again purely imaginary and negative. Because the real part of the damping moment is negative, the system is stable. To gain further physical insight into this behaviour, the system behaviour is examined for low and high speeds in terms of the internal moments. For low speeds, when Ω<<1 i.e. ω<<ωk, s¯1≈-1-(jΩ/2) and s¯2≈jΩ/2, it can be seen that s¯1 is a stable root with negative real part and s¯2 is on the verge of instability, i.e. the real part is zero. For high speeds, when Ω>>1, s¯1≈(-1-Ω-jΩ)/2 and s¯2≈(Ω+jΩ)/2, where s¯1 is again a stable root with negative real part and s¯2 now an unstable root with positive real part. For low speeds, the unstable root s¯2≈jΩ/2 is substituted into equation (7) to give (9)-Ω24︸inertial> >moment+jΩ2︸damping> >moment-jΩ2︸cross>->coupledstiffness> >moment=0

The inertial moment, -Ω2/4, is negligible compared to the other moments, since Ω<<1. Hence, in this speed range, the system vibrates at the frequency when the damping moment and the cross-coupled stiffness moments roughly balance each other. Similarly, for the high speed range, substituting the unstable root s¯2≈(Ω+jΩ)/2 into equation (7) gives (10)jΩ2︸inertial> >moment+Ω(1+j)2︸damping> >moment-jΩ2︸cross>->coupledstiffness> >moment≈0

In this case, the damping moment (Ω(1+j))/2 is small compared to the other moments because Ω>>1. Hence, in this speed range, the system vibrates at a frequency where the inertia moment and the cross-coupled stiffness moments balance each other. The way in which the gyroscopic moment affects the dynamic behaviour is now discussed by considering equation (6). The solution to this equation is (11)s¯1,2=-1+jβΩ±(1-jβΩ)2+2jΩ2

The Argand diagrams showing the internal moments corresponding to the unstable root are plotted in Figure 6 for β = 0.1, 0.25, 0.5 and 0.75. By comparing these figures with Figure 5(a), it can be seen that the gyroscopic moment has both real and imaginary parts, and has the effect of reducing the positive real part of the damping moment and to increase the imaginary part; it also has a greater influence on the damping moment as β increases. It is notable that except for the cross-coupled stiffness moment, all the other moments are affected by the change of β. It can be seen that when β = 0.5, the real part of the damping moment is zero; it is imaginary and positive, and balances the cross-coupled stiffness moment. Similarly, the gyroscopic moment balances the inertia moment. Thus, when β=1/2, the conical mode of vibration is stabilised. It can also be seen that when β>0.5 as in Figure 6(d), then the real part of the damping moment is negative and hence the system is stable. Figure 6.
Argand diagram of the moments from the unstable root of the equation of angular motion of a turbocharger with journal bearings in rigid housings with the gyroscopic effects: (a) β=0.1, (b) β=0.25, (c) β=0.5 and (d) β=0.75 (0≤Ω≤10).

The asymptotic behaviour for low and high speeds is determined as before. For low speeds, when Ω<<1, s¯1≈-1+jβΩ-(jΩ/2) is a stable root and s¯2≈jΩ/2 is on the verge of instability (purely imaginary). For high speeds, when Ω>>1, s¯1≈-1/2 is a purely real root and s¯2≈(-1+jβΩ+-β2Ω2)/2≈jβΩ is on the verge of instability. Substituting the root s¯2≈jΩ/2 into equation (6) for low speeds, gives (12)-Ω24︸inertialmoment+jΩ2︸dampingmoment+βΩ22︸gyroscopicmoment-jΩ2︸cross>->coupledstiffness> >moment≈0

Equation (12) shows that the damping moment and the cross-coupled moment are equal and opposite, while the gyroscopic moment balances the inertial moment when β=1/2. Substituting the root s¯2≈jβΩ into equation (6) for high speeds gives (13)-β2Ω2︸inertialmoment+jβΩ︸dampingmoment+β2Ω2︸gyroscopicmoment-jΩ2︸cross>->coupledstiffness> >moment≈0

It can be seen that the inertial moment balances the gyroscopic moment, while the damping moment counteracts the cross-coupled stiffness moment. Similar to the low speed range, here the damping moment perfectly balances the cross-coupled stiffness moment when β=1/2. Considering s¯1,2 from equation (11) when β=1/2, the roots factorise into (14)s¯1,2=-1+jΩ/2±(1+jΩ/2)22 giving s¯1=jΩ/2, s¯2=-1 (purely real and purely imaginary root). Thus, it can be seen that β=1/2 is a threshold value where the unstable root with positive real part becomes purely imaginary. Physically, this means that the turbocharger whirls in its perturbed position without any further growth of amplitude.

Finally, Figure 7 shows the way in which the real part of the unstable root of the characteristic equation changes with speed. It is clear from this graph, that the conical mode is stabilised when β=1/2 and that for values of β≥1/2, the system is stable. The analysis, here, demonstrates the significance of the threshold value of β=1/2 in stabilising the conical whirl. However, the real turbocharger has an asymmetric rather than a symmetric rotor and often has floating ring bearings. Further investigation of the effects of gyroscopic moments in the system is conducted in the following section. Figure 7.
Graph showing the relationship between non-dimensional speed and the real part of the roots of the characteristic equation of angular motion of a simplified model of a turbocharger for different values of β.

sec.title: Gyroscopic effect in an asymmetric turbocharger rotor with floating ring bearings
sec.p:
Figure 8 shows a schematic diagram of an asymmetric rotor of a turbocharger with floating ring bearings and the forces acting on the rotor due to both the transverse and the angular motion discussed above; la,lb are the distances of the centre of gravity of the rotor from the turbine and the compressor bearing centres, respectively. Assuming a rigid rotor of mass 2m mounted in two identical bearings with full-film, the equations of transverse motion of the turbocharger in the inner-film of the bearing is given as9 (15)fa+fb=-2mr··1c where r1c={r1c,s1c}T, r1c,s1c are the co-ordinates of the centre of gravity of the rotor. fa={Fra,Fsa}T is the vector of oil-film forces on the rotor in the bearing adjacent to the turbine and fb={Frb,Fsb}T is the vector of oil-film forces in the bearing adjacent to the compressor. As mentioned previously, it is assumed that the outer oil-film in the floating ring bearings can be modelled as a viscous damper. Using the oil-film forces given in equation (2) for the bearings, the bearing forces are given by9 (16)fa=2A(r·1a-r·a)+AωΓ(r1a-ra) (17)fb=2A(r·1b-r·b)+AωΓ(r1b-rb) where ri={ri,si}T, i=a,b,1a,1b, in which ra,b are the vectors of co-ordinates of the floating ring centres CBa,b in the turbine and compressor end bearings, and r1a,1b are the corresponding vectors of co-ordinates of the journal dynamic centres CDa,b. The equation of angular motion with the gyroscopic effect as seen in Figure 8 is given by (18)Iθ··+JωΓθ·+fb TL-fa TL=0 where L=[lb 00 la]. The linear co-ordinate transformation can be done, using (19)r1c=r1b+Ll(r1a-r1b) (20)θ=(r1b-r1a)l where the derivatives of θ are given by the corresponding derivatives of the right hand side of equation (20). Substituting for the forces from equations (16) and (17), and using the transformation in equations (19) and (20), the equation of motion in matrix form is given by (21)2m[r··1b(1-lbl)+r··1albl]+2A[(r·1a-r·a)+(r·1b-r·b)] +AωΓ[(r1a-ra)+(r1b-rb)]=0 Figure 8.
Co-ordinate system and forces acting on the rigid shaft model of a turbocharger with floating ring bearings including gyroscopic moments: la and lb are the distances between the bearing centres and the rotor centre of gravity; Jω is the angular momentum of the rotor, where ω is the spin speed and J is the polar moment of inertia of the rotor; Jωθ·, Jωφ· are the gyroscopic moments about y and x axes, respectively.

The constraint forces at the interface of the ring and the outer-film (external damper) are given by (22)f=r∧=γr· where r∧={Rr,Rs}T; Rr,s are the constraining forces applied by the outer-film that is the external damper and γ is the damping coefficient of the outer-film of the floating ring bearings. Combining equations (16) and (17) with equation (22) results in (23)γr·a-2A(r·1a-r·a)-AωΓ(r1a-ra)=0 (24)γr·b-2A(r·1b-r·b)-AωΓ(r1b-rb)=0

Combining equations (21), (23) and (24) and assuming solutions of the form r=Reλt, gives the non-dimensional matrix equation (25)[γ∧s¯+2s¯Ω00-2s¯-Ω00-Ωγ∧s¯+2s¯00Ω-2s¯0000γ∧s¯+2s¯Ω00-2s¯-Ω00-Ωγ∧s¯+2s¯00Ω-2s¯-2s¯-Ω-2s¯-Ω2s¯(1+s¯Lb)Ω2s¯(1+s¯(1-Lb))ΩΩ-2s¯Ω-2s¯-Ω2s¯(1+s¯Lb)-Ω2s¯(1+s¯(1-Lb))4Las¯2ΩLa-4Lbs¯-2ΩLb-4s¯(La+s¯)-2Ω(La+2βs¯)4s¯(Lb+s¯)2Ω(Lb+2βs¯)-2ΩLa4Las¯2ΩLb-4Lbs¯2Ω(La+2βs¯)-4s¯(La+s¯)-2Ω(Lb+2βs¯)4s¯(Lb+s¯)]{RaSaRbSbR1aS1aR1bS1b}=0,

where, La,b=la,b/l. Figure 9(a) shows the real part of the root of the characteristic equation of the determinant of equation (25). For a typical turbocharger shown in Figure 2(a) using La=0.01,Lb=0.99, for β<1/2, the system has an unstable conical mode and an unstable cylindrical mode with positive Re{s¯}. However, the real part of the conical mode becomes zero for β=1/2. For β>1/2, the system has a stable conical mode, with the Re{s¯} being negative. The stability of the in-phase whirl mode remains unaffected since β does not directly affect the transverse motion. The imaginary part of the unstable roots for different values of β is shown in Figure 9(b). This plot represents an overlay of theoretical waterfall plots for three different values of β. Since the conical mode is stable for β>1/2, only the corresponding in-phase whirl mode is seen in Figure 9(b). It can be seen that the in-phase whirl frequencies increase as β is increased. This is probably due to the stiffening nature of the gyroscopic effect which increases the whirl frequency. Examination of Figure 9(a) shows that
the conical unstable mode stabilises as β increases, i.e. as the ratio of the polar to the transverse moment of inertia of the rotor increases;
the rotor is neutrally stable when β=1/2.
Figure 9.
(a) Variation of growth/decay rate of sub-synchronous whirl amplitude (real part of the roots) with β for a turbocharger with floating ring bearings, when plotted against speed (γ∧=10,La=0.01,Lb=0.99) and (b) corresponding variation of sub-synchronous whirl frequencies (imaginary part of the unstable roots).

This confirms that β=1/2 is the threshold value for the stability of the conical whirl of a turbocharger with full-film floating ring bearings; this value is unaffected by the asymmetry of the rotor and the presence of an external damper support to the bearings.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article has described the way in which the gyroscopic moment can stabilise the conical mode of a high-speed automotive turbocharger. To isolate the effect of the gyroscopic moment, a simple model of a symmetric rotor and rigidly supported full-film bearings was considered, while the gravitational effects were ignored. This analysis showed that the gyroscopic coefficient which is the ratio of the polar to the transverse inertia of the rotor plays the key role in stabilising the conical whirl induced by the angular motion of the rotor. The threshold value of the gyroscopic coefficient for which the conical whirl mode is on the verge of instability is ½. For values greater than this, the mode is stable. The gyroscopic coefficient has the effect of changing the magnitudes and the relative phases of the internal moments acting on the rotor system due to the oil-filled bearings. The system is stabilised when the damping moment is in anti-phase with the cross-coupled stiffness moment so that the real part of the root to the characteristic equation is zero. A linear stability analysis of a turbocharger model with an asymmetric rotor and floating ring bearings was also performed. It was also found that the threshold ratio of ½ for the gyroscopic coefficient holds for this more realistic system.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was partially funded by a Rayleigh Scholarship from the Institute of Sound and Vibration Research, University of Southampton, UK.

The death of whirl and whip - Use of externally pressurized bearings and seals for control of whirl and whip instability. ORBIT, Fourth Quarter, 2001.
HoltCSan AndresLSahaySTangPLa RueGGjikaK. Test response and nonlinear analysis of a turbocharger supported on floating ring bearings. J Vib Acoust 2005; 127: 107–115.

Alsaeed A. Dynamic stability evaluation of an automotive turbocharger rotor-bearing system. Master’s Thesis, Mechanical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 2005.
GunterEJChenWJ. Dynamics of rotor-bearing systems. Charlottesville, VA: RODYN Vibration Analysis Inc., 2003.

Gunter EJ and Chen WJ. Dynamic analysis of a turbocharger in floating bushing bearings. In: Proceedings of the third international symposium on stability control of rotating machinery (ISCORMA-3), Cleveland, OH, 19–23 September 2005. New York, NY: Hindawi Publishing Corporation.
San AndrésLKerthJ. Thermal effects on the performance of floating ring bearings for turbochargers. Proc IMechE Part J: J Engineering Tribology 2004; 218(5): 437–450.

Holmes R, Brennan MJ and Gottrand B. Vibration of an automotive turbocharger- a case study. In: Proceedings of the eighth international conference on Vibrations in Rotating Machinery (VIRM-8), Swansea, UK, 7–9 September 2004, pp.445–450. New York, NY: Wiley.

Tondl A. Some problems of self-excited vibration of rotors. Monographs and memoranda of the National Research Institute for Machine Design. Monograph no. 17, 1974. Bechovice, Czech Republic: National Research Institute for Machine Design.

def.p: clearance between the journal and the fixed housing
turbine end bearing centre (a) and compressor end bearing centre (b)
turbine end journal static centre (a) and compressor end journal static centre (b)
turbine end journal dynamic centre (a) and compressor end journal dynamic centre (b)
oil-film force vectors at the turbine end b(a) and the compressor end (b) bearings
polar moment of inertia of the rotor assembly
distances of the rotor centre of gravity from the turbine bearing centre (a) and the compressor bearing centre (b)
moment about r and s axes
co-ordinate vectors of the floating ring centre at the turbine (a) and compressor end (b) bearings
co-ordinate vectors of the journal dynamic centre at the turbine (a) and compressor end bearings (b)
co-ordinate vector of the centre of gravity of the asymmetric rotor (={r1c,s1c}T)
amplitude of the journal response (i=a,b,1a,1b) of the turbocharger
non-dimensional root of the characteristic equation for the symmetric rotor with rigidly supported bearings (journal bearings)
angular co-ordinates of the rotor centre of gravity
amplitudes of angular vibration corresponding to θ,φ
